title: Chicoreus brevifrons
text:
Chicoreus brevifrons, common name the West Indian murex, is a <a href="species">species</a> of predatory <a href="sea%20snail">sea snail</a>, a <a href="marine%20%28ocean%29">marine</a> <a href="gastropod">gastropod</a> <a href="mollusk">mollusk</a> in the family <a href="Muricidae">Muricidae</a>, the murex snails.
Shell description.
The maximum <a href="gastropod%20shell">shell</a> length of this species is up to 150 mm.
The shell of "C. brevifrons" is relatively elongate, and has a typical muricid outline. Three axial varices are present along its <a href="body%20whorl">body whorl</a>, and they are ornamented by characteristic expanded hollow spines. It also presents flat spiral cords in the interspaces of its surface. The anterior canal is well-developed, akin to several other <a href="Muricidae">Muricidae</a> snails.
Distribution.
"C. brevifrons" occurs in the Western <a href="Central%20Atlantic">Central Atlantic</a>, from the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>, the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a>, the <a href="Antilles">Antilles</a> to <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>.
Ecology.
Habitat.
This sea snail dwells on mud flats in protected <a href="bays">bays</a> and <a href="lagoons">lagoons</a>. It is commonly found near <a href="oyster">oyster</a> banks, as well as <a href="mangrove">mangrove</a> areas.
Feeding.
"C. brevifrons" is an active <a href="predator">predator</a> of other molluscs such as <a href="oysters">oysters</a> and <a href="clams">clams</a>.
Human uses.
This sea snail is locally collected for food, and is consumed raw or boiled.
The shell is often sold as a souvenir in local markets.
